","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PATH2201","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PATH2201 - Processes in Disease","description":"

Lectures, online modules, tutorials and practical classes (histopathology and macroscopic pathology sessions) aimed at increasing understanding of important disease processes. Comparisons between normal and abnormal cell, tissue and organ function will be made. Includes processes of cell and tissue degeneration, acute and chronic inflammation, regeneration and repair, infection, atherosclerosis, thrombosis, embolism and infarction. Particular examples include diseases of practical importance such as pneumonia, tuberculosis, pulmonary embolism and myocardial infarction. Aberrations of cell growth introduces neoplasia with examples of common tumours.

Students will complete a 1-hour mid-term exam . The exam will consist of 10 multiple choice questions and 1 short-answer question on any of the content covered prior to to exam.

 

Feedback:

Feedback will be provided in tutorial 1 week after the exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2175ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2175ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2975ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7175c258dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End-of-course exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

Students will complete a 2-hour written exam. Part A will consist of 20 multiple choice questions, Part B will consist of 4 short-answer questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2175ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2175ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2975ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79750658dbb6d010eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pathology assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The Pathology assignment assesses awareness of pathological processes, the roles of scientific literature in medical/scientific research and education, and the ability to utilise and cite scientific literature at an academic standard. Reflective practice will also be assessed.

Students will find a specimen of interest from the Musuem of Human disease that is relevant to one of the pathological processes studied in this course:

  • acute inflammation
  • chronic inflammation
  • thrombosis, embolism & infaction (vascular disease)
  • neoplasia

Students will write a report which outlines background information on the disease, how medical research has improved understanding of the disease, and a research question, that if answered, would further enhance understaning of the disease. The report should utilise and cite appropriate medical/scientific literature at an an academic standard.

 

Feedback:

 

Students will recieve peer-feedback on a draft of their assignments. Students will receive marks and feedback via Moodle 10 days after the submission date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2175ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2975ce18dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7975c258dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

During the semester, students will complete short online quizzes at the end of each online module. Quizzes can be attempted multiple times and the highest score achieved before the Feedback/Integration session for the current topic will be recorded. Students will also answer questions during the in-class Integration/Feedback sessions via the UNSW Lecture Recordings+ service. For this assessment, 50% of the marks will come from quizzes in the online modules; 50% will come from Integration/Feedback sessions.

 

Feedback:

Feedback will be provided online at the completion of each online module quiz. Additional feedback will be provided by the lecturer during the in-class Integration/Feedback session.

Students will complete a 2-hour written exam. Part A will consist of 20 multiple choice questions, Part B will consist of 4 short-answer questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6e5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e65b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a96193d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

During the semester, students will complete short online quizzes at the end of each online module. Quizzes can be attempted multiple times and the highest score achieved before the Feedback/Integration session for the current topic will be recorded. Students will also answer questions during the in-class Integration/Feedback sessions via the UNSW Lecture Recordings+ service. For this assessment, 50% of the marks will come from quizzes in the online modules; 50% will come from Integration/Feedback sessions.

 

Feedback:

Feedback will be provided online at the completion of each online module quiz. Additional feedback will be provided by the lecturer during the in-class Feedback/Integration sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6e5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e65b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"865b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will complete a 1-hour exam which will consist of multiple choice and short-answer questions on any of the content covered prior to the exam.

 

Feedback:

 

Feedback will be provided in a tutorial after the exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6e5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e65b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"de5b0aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pathology assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The Pathology assignment assesses awareness of pathological processes, the roles of scientific literature in medical/scientific research and education, and the ability to utilise and cite scientific literature at an academic standard. Reflective practice will also be assessed.

Students will find a specimen of interest from the Musuem of Human disease that is relevant to one of the pathological processes studied in this course:

  • acute inflammation
  • chronic inflammation
  • thrombosis, embolism & infaction (vascular disease)
  • neoplasia

Students will write a report which outlines background information on the disease, explains how medical research has improved understanding of the disease, and presents a research question, that if answered, would further enhance understaning of the disease. The report should utilise and cite appropriate medical/scientific literature at an an academic standard.

 

Feedback:

Students will receive peer-feedback on a draft of the assignment. Students will also receive marks and feedback via Moodle 10 days after submission.

contentlets.description:
Lectures, online modules, tutorials and practical classes (macroscopic pathology sessions) aimed at increasing understanding of important disease processes. Comparisons between normal and abnormal cell, tissue and organ function will be made. Includes processes of cell and tissue degeneration, acute and chronic inflammation, regeneration and repair, infection, atherosclerosis, thrombosis, embolism and infarction. Particular examples include diseases of practical importance such as pneumonia, rheumatoid arthritis, pulmonary embolism and myocardial infarction. Aberrations of cell growth introduces neoplasia with examples of common tumours.

For more detailed information, please see  the Course Outline below.
contentlets.title: Processes in Disease for Health and Exercise Science

Recent advances in understanding molecular mechanisms of acute and chronic inflammation, infection, allergy and autoimmune diseases. Detailed discussion of mediators of these processes, including cytokines and growth factors. Systemic pathology of various organs and tissues, including the cardiovascular (e.g. coronary artery disease) and respiratory systems (e.g. asthma), with an emphasis on molecular pathogenesis. Laboratory classes introduce 'state-of-the-art' research and diagnostic techniques.


Note: Students are advised that previous and concurrent study of Anatomy, Physiology, Biochemistry or Immunology would be an advantage.


For more detailed information, please click on "Course Outline" in box below.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dc662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961977","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Examination assessing theoretical and practical content knowledge. It is proposed that the examination will consist of 4 Short answer questions, 20 MCQs (both assessing theoretical content) and 2 images that are retrieved from the practical course content (assessing practical aspects of the course).

Students attempt this assessment as individuals in 2hrs during the end of term examination period.

Examines understanding disease processes and their relevance to an underlying example of disease that has been covered throughout the course. Feedback can be provided on an individual basis if students seek it.
 

           

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"08662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27562577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual and team performance in tutorial quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Quiz assessing content knowledge. 

Students attempt this assessment as individuals and as teams. This forms the basis of collaborative learning for understanding complex molecular mechanisms and disease processes. Students will be required to complete pre-reading and tutorial objectives prior to the tutorial. Therefore, quizzes in the tutorials will form the basis of the tutorial itself, thus encouraging a flipped classroom approach.


Verbal feedback is given once the quiz has been marked by the Tutor. Marks are given to students at the time of quiz completion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"44662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27562577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Impact Symposium","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will design a collaborative presentation to pitch a 'research problem or issue' from the last 15 years. The style of presentation is determined by the team. Styles include but are not limited to a traditional PowerPoint presentation, a short film, a panel discussion. This task addresses research integrated learning and to a lesser extent work integrated learning. Research on a disease topic with supporting medical research literature is required. Students will be mentored throughout the course by researchers in the areas of immunology, infection and inflammation. Mentors should ideally be ECR scientists who can guide and advise students on their research thinking and practice. This addresses ECR development within SoMS. Students will be required to reflect and blog on these experiences.

The marks for the assessment task (total worth = 30%) will be broken down in the following way: 

Assessment/Evaluation (of content) by teachers and peers will be worth 20%

Team Peer and Self Evaluation on Team Roles and Contribution will be worth 5%

ePortfolio / Research Experience blog will be worth 5%   

Graduate attributes in teamwork, research enquiry, critical thinking (reflective practice) and communication will be addressed.


Feedback on assessment progress will be given to each group by the mentor for research thinking and practice and by consultation with Ms Gwyn Jones (Learning Centre, UNSW) for academic skills development.

Assessment outcomes will be posted on Moodle.

Feedback on assessment outcomes will be given in week 13 in a 1hr interactive session between students, the mentors, Ms Gwyn Jones and A/Prof Patsie Polly.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"08662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"44662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c8662577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f562577dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Summative exam focused on pathological process questions (theory and practical).

Verbal feedback is given once the exam has been marked by the Tutor.

Assessment outcomes will be posted on Moodle


Course Learning Outcomes:

  1. Describe and distinguish between the causes, pathogenic molecular mechanisms, macroscopic and microscopic appearances and clinical consequences of inflammation, immune responses to infection, allergy, autoimmunity, and effects of systemic inflammation on cardiovascular, gastrointestinal and respiratory systems
  2. Discuss and debate state-of-the-art research and concepts of disease.
  3. Understand and explain the relevance of laboratory techniques and analysing outcomes in the diagnosis of human disease.

PATH3206 aims to promote understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms underlying neoplasia. There is detailed discussion of molecular carcinogenesis, the metastatic process, and techniques for diagnosis, incorporating recent advances in molecular oncology (genomics, metabolism, immunotherapy, targeted therapeutics, systems biology). Discussion will integrate recent and emerging research findings and develop communication skills and critical thinking. Topics covered include neoplasia of the colon, breast, stomach, skin, lung, haematological, paediatric and reproductive tract neoplasms.


To understand these processes, you will draw on your prior knowledge of anatomy, histology, molecular biology, biochemistry and physiology.


For those wishing to pursue a career in research or hospital based laboratory work, the course will not only develop basic knowledge of molecular processes, but also provide a framework for understanding how these processes link to the modern practice of medicine. Similarly, for those who may wish to pursue a career in the health sciences, the course will provide an understanding of the cellular and molecular processes underlying clinical manifestations of neoplasia.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0824d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619ad","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Team and Individual Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

There will be quizzes held in the tutorial sessions consisting of MCQs. Some tutorial quizzes will be undertaken by the individual student and then by the team, others just individually. Pre-reading for the quizzes is specified in the tutorial outlines of the manual. Tutors feedback to students following each quiz and discuss the concepts underlying each question.

Feedback:

Feedback will be provided online at the completion of the team attempt. Additional feedback will be provided by the tutor at the completion of the quiz. For each quiz, 50% of the final mark will be from the individual attempt and 50% will be from the team attempt.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0824d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a96199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"0c24d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4424d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8024d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f14d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Team Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment requires students working in teams to undertake a critical assessment of media coverage of recent cancer research. Teams will present their findings in both a written report and in mixed media format at a research symposium.

This assessment task focuses on the following graduate attributes: Information acquisition, evaluation and synthesis; Effective communication in both oral and written formats; Teamwork, collaborative and management skills; Research inquiry.

The Task 

1. Choose a recent (i.e. within the last year) media story about cancer (e.g. from TV, online, print, radio).

2. Identify and assess the primary research and review publication(s) relevant to the media story (preferably including relevant institutional press releases).

3. Perform a critical evaluation of the media reporting of the underlying research. (10%)

4. Each group will submit both a written report and present their findings using flexible format (video, animation, audio, live presentation, poster etc). (20%)

Feedback:

A written and verbal feedback is provided after the presentation as well as a final mark.

A 2-hour end of course examination. The questions assess all the learning outcomes. This examination encourages an in-depth engagement with pathology within a clinical context. The questions vary in style; some questions may have two parts. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0824d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a96199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4424d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8024d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fb14d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ef14d62bdb399850eb6b147a3a96195b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

A mid-session exam will be conducted. The examination will include material covered in Weeks 1-5 of PATH3206. The skills achieved by mastering the tutorial quizzes will be assessed in this exam.

Feedback:

Feedback will be provided in the tutorial in the week following the mid-session exam.

This course will be beneficial to students wishing to pursue careers in the health sciences, especially medicine (in particular rehabilitation medicine), biomedical research or hospital-based laboratory work. A sound understanding of musculoskeletal pathology should provide an effective framework from which to approach diagnosis and management of common clinical scenarios that you may well encounter in your future careers. The course covers bone and joint disease, neuromuscular disease, musculoskeletal trauma and primary and secondary bone neoplasms.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"235b4aafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of course written examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

At the end of the term there will be a written exam that accounts for 45% of the final mark for the course. The questions assess all the learning outcomes and encourage an in-depth understanding of the pathology of musculoskeletal diseases in a clinical and research context. Marks will be weighted as follows: short answer questions 25%; and objective items 20%. The short answer questions vary in style but are intended to provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate their understanding of the topic and their ability to integrate ideas rather than simple regurgitation of facts. The objective items consist of 20 multiple choice questions where the best or most appropriate answer is chosen from the alternatives provided. Feedback will be given in the form of a final mark as part of the student end of course grade.

\n

Evidence Based Symposium: This is a group presentation in week 7 and comprises 15% of the final mark. Of the15%, 2.5% will be determined by members of the group, 2.5% by peer assessment and 10% will be allocated by two academic staff based on content, presentation, use of relevant literature and ability to answer questions on the topic. A detailed guide on the tasks involved and rubrics of the marking schemes will be provided in a form of a 1-hour presentation by the course convenor. A 1-hour feedback session will be carried out in week 9 outlining students performance and their marks.

These weekly tutorial quizzes are individual assessments and will comprise10% of the final mark (2% for each of 5 individual quizzes). Each quiz contains 5 multiple choice questions, primarily based on the two lectures given during same week and a pre-reading indicated on your course manual. Students are strongly advised to attend and review the lectures and perform the allocated pre-reading before the tutorial. The recommended pre-readings are only a guide, additional reading on the subject from the prescribed textbooks is highly recommended. At the end of each quiz, the tutor will give structured feedback on the answers. This will clarify challenging questions and concepts, provide tutorials that are tailored to each group and aims to encourage discussions. 

\n

Students will complete a 45minute written Midsession exam (date and time to be announced). This exam will consist 5 multiple choice questions and 3 short answer questions that may include interpretation of diagnostic image(s), describing pathophysiological processes, description and diagnosis of a macroscopic specimen and/or writing histopathological reports. This will constitute10% of the final mark of the course. General feedback about the mid-session exam will be provided to each tutorial group. Students who performed poorly in 3 or more tutorial quizzes and/or the Mid-session exam may receive individual feedback either face-to-face or online. The aim of this assessment is to provide timely feedback on your progress and provide you with remedial assistance if needed.

contentlets.description: This course will be beneficial to students wishing to pursue careers in the health sciences, especially medicine (in particular rehabilitation medicine), biomedical research or hospital-based laboratory work. A sound understanding of musculoskeletal pathology should provide an effective framework from which to approach diagnosis and management of common clinical scenarios that you may well encounter in your future careers. The course covers bone and joint disease, neuromuscular disease, musculoskeletal trauma and primary and secondary bone neoplasms.

This course will be beneficial to students wishing to pursue careers in the health sciences, especially medicine (in particular immunology, biomedical research or hospital-based laboratory work. An advanced understanding of clinical immunology should provide an effective framework from which to approach diagnosis and management of common clinical scenarios that you may well encounter in your future careers. 


The course covers the components of innate and adaptive immunity and their cross-talk, clinical and pathological basis of immunodeficiency, hypersensitivity disorders, autoimmunity, cancer immunology and infection immunity in clinical and research context such as immuno-diagnostics, immune-modulation and immunotherapy, systems immunology and big data immunology and vaccine immunology.

Progressive research project: This is a small group research work where students will  submit a written research proposal on week 7 and present their proposal on weeks 9 and 10. The written research report and presentation are based on cutting-edge topics in clinical immunology that are organised, designed, delivered and assessed by students working in small groups and facilitated by a designated academic mentor. This comprises 20% of the final mark. Of the 20%, 5% will be determined by members of the group, 5% by peer assessment and 10% will be allocated by two academic staff based on the submitted written paper and quality of the presentation.
